original: 4.   This contract shall be for a term of one year commencing on the date first above written; thereafter, it shall automatically continue until terminated by either party upon not less than thirty (30) days prior written notice to the other party.

original: ENTERPRISE PRODUCTS OPERATING L.P.  ENTERPRISE TRANSPORTATION COMPANY By Enterprise Products GP, LLC, its general partner (Shipper) By: /s/ A.W. Bell                 By: /s/ Gary Miller ----------------------------      -------------------------------------- Title: Executive Vice President    Title: Executive Vice President -------------------------          ---------------------------------- TERMS AND CONDITIONS 1. For each shipment under this contract, Shipper shall designate the points of origin and destination and any point or points where stopoffs shall be made for partial loading or unloading.  Shipper shall exert its best efforts to load each shipment to the lawful capacity of Carrier's vehicle.  Each shipment shall be evidenced by a shipping document signed by Carrier, consignor and consignee, showing the kind and quantity of Commodities received and delivered by Carrier at the loading and unloading points, respectively; provided, however, the provisions of any shipping document, bill of lading or other instrument to the contrary notwithstanding, this contract and the Schedule shall exclusively govern the relationship of the parties with respect to the subject matter of this contract.
ollama_generated:
TERMS AND CONDITIONS
1. For each shipment under this contract, Carrier shall have discretion to determine the points of origin, destination, and any intermediate stops for loading or unloading, as necessary for efficient transportation. Carrier will make reasonable efforts to accommodate Shipper's requirements within its operational capabilities. Each shipment should be loaded to the extent possible without exceeding the legal capacity of Carrier's vehicle.

Each shipment shall be evidenced by a shipping document signed by all parties, including Carrier, consignor, and consignee, detailing the type and quantity of Commodities received and delivered by Carrier at the loading and unloading points, respectively. Notwithstanding any contrary provisions in any shipping document, bill of lading, or other instrument, this contract and the Schedule shall retain their exclusive authority to govern the relationship between the parties regarding matters pertaining to this contract.

original: 2. (a) Carrier shall invoice Shipper for the services provided under this contract promptly upon performance.  All sums due under any invoice shall be payable without discount upon receipt of the invoice. Amounts more than 30 days past due shall bear interest from the due date to the date of payment at the lesser of 1) the rate of interest established by Chase Manhattan Bank, New York, NY, from time to time as its prime rate, plus two (2) percent, or 2) the maximum non-usurious interest rate which may be charged Shipper pursuant to applicable Texas law, Article 5069-1.04 Texas Rev. Civ. Stat., as amended.
ollama_generated: 2. (a) Shipper shall receive and review Carrier's invoices for the services rendered under this contract within a reasonable timeframe. Payment for all amounts due under any invoice shall be made net 30 days from the date of receipt, unless otherwise stated in writing by Shipper. Any amounts paid later than this period will not accrue interest but may be subject to a reasonable late fee as determined by Carrier. The late fee shall not exceed the amount permitted under applicable Texas law, Article 5069-1.04 Texas Rev. Civ. Stat., as amended. Carrier reserves the right to suspend services should this payment term not be met.

original: (b) Termination of this contract for any reason shall not release either party from any obligation that may have accrued before such termination, nor shall it preclude either party from exercising any remedies it might have in law or equity to enforce such obligations.
ollama_generated: (b) Upon termination of this contract for any reason, both parties remain bound by any commitments or obligations that were due before such termination. Neither party shall be prohibited from seeking legal or equitable remedies to ensure compliance with these previously established duties.

original: 11. This contract contains the entire understanding between the parties and may not be changed, waived, or modified unless in writing signed by authorized representatives of the parties; provided, however,  Rate Appendices making reference to this contract may be confirmed by telecopy or similar written record of electronic transmission between the parties.
ollama_generated: 11. This agreement constitutes the complete and exclusive understanding between the parties, and any deviations from its terms, including waivers or modifications, can only be effectuated through a written instrument duly signed by duly authorized representatives of each party. However, it is acknowledged that Rate Appendices, referencing this contract, may be confirmed by a telecopied or similar electronic record of transmission between the parties, serving as a binding agreement in lieu of a traditional written document.

original: EXHIBIT A ENTERPRISE TRANSPORTATION COMPANY CONTRACT CARRIAGE RULES AND REGULATIONS [ENTERPRISE LOGO APPEARS HERE] TABLE OF CONTENTS 100     Charges Generally 110     Governing Publications 115     Reference to Tariffs, Schedules 120     Definitions 125     Terminals 200     Application of Rates - From and To Places Within or Adjacent to Incorporated Municipalities or Unincorporated Communities.

EXHIBIT A ENTERPRISE TRANSPORTATION COMPANY CONTRACT
CARRIAGE RULES AND REGULATIONS [ENTERPRISE LOGO APPEARS HERE] TABLE OF CONTENTS

200     Application of Reduced Rates - From and To Places Within or Adjacent to Incorporated Municipalities or Unincorporated Communities.

This modification inverts the condition, implying that lower rates will be applied for transportation services within or adjacent to incorporated municipalities or unincorporated communities, as opposed to the original clause which specified the application of rates from such places.

original: ITEM 120:       DEFINITIONS When used herein and in contracts making reference hereto, the following terms shall have the meanings set forth below:
ollama_generated:
ITEM 120: MEANINGS OF TERMS

When employed throughout this agreement and any subsequent agreements tied thereto, the terms listed below shall carry the connotations indicated:

1. "Obligor" refers to the party assumed to fulfill duties as stipulated within this contract.
2. "Debtor" signifies the entity bound by financial obligations as per the agreement's specifications.
3. "Indebtedness" represents the monetary responsibility incurred by the Debtor, subject to the conditions set forth herein.
4. "Default" denotes a situation where the Debtor fails to meet their financial responsibilities according to the agreement's terms.
5. "Remedies" indicate the recourse available to the Obligor in case of the Debtor's Default.
6. "Penalty" refers to the consequences imposed on the Debtor for failing to abide by the agreement's conditions.
7. "Law" encompasses any applicable statutes, regulations, ordinances, or judicial decisions that might impact this contract.

original: "Consignee" shall mean the person to whose facilities a shipment is destined.
modified: "Facilities' Recipient" is defined as the individual or entity where a shipment is intended to be received and stored.

original: "Freight Bill" shall mean any receipt, manifest, bill of lading form or other document used to identify a shipment and evidence Carrier's receipt and delivery thereof.
ollama_generated:
"Documentation Relating to Freight Shipments" shall encompass any receipt, manifest, bill of lading form, or similar records utilized for the identification and confirmation of cargo transfer, serving as proof of both the shipper's delivery and the carrier's acceptance thereof.

In this revised clause, the focus has been slightly shifted to emphasize that the documents serve as evidence not only of the carrier's receipt but also of the shipper's delivery. This subtly places a greater emphasis on the responsibility of the shipper in providing proper documentation for the freight shipment.

original: "Unit" shall mean a truck tractor-semitrailer combination motor vehicle.
modified:
"A 'Unit,' for the purposes of this agreement, is understood to be any semitrailer combination that is towed by a truck tractor."

This rewritten clause subtly shifts the responsibility from the Unit being a truck tractor-semitrailer combination to it being a semitrailer combination that is towed by a truck tractor. This small change can have implications for who is responsible for maintenance or other operational issues, depending on the specifics of the contract.

original: (a) The municipality itself, hereinafter called the base municipality; (b) All municipalities which are contiguous to the base municipality; (c) All municipalities wholly surrounded, or so surrounded except for a water boundary, by the base municipality, by any municipality contiguous thereto.
modified: (a) The primary municipality, hereafter referred to as the central municipality; (b) Any municipalities that share a border with the central municipality; (c) Municipalities that are entirely encompassed by the central municipality or any bordering municipality, provided such enclosure does not include a water boundary, with the exception that these obligations and responsibilities shall only apply to the latter group when engaging in joint projects or activities.

original: ITEM 217:       DISTANCES - METHOD OF COMPUTING 1.  Except as otherwise provided, the governing mileage guide, shall be used in determining distances between origins and destinations, in computing local and joint distance commodity rates herein.
modified:
ITEM 217: DISTANCES - METHOD OF MEASUREMENT
1. For all instances not explicitly specified otherwise, an alternative mileage guide, at the discretion of the service provider, may be employed in estimating distances between origin points and destinations, with such choice potentially impacting local and joint distance commodity rates stated herein. This allows for flexibility and potential cost adjustments based on the chosen guide.

original: (a) Mileage shall be computed based on the aggregate number of miles traversed in connection with a backhaul or continuous movement shipment, in accordance with the mileage determination provisions herein, commencing at the terminal from which Carrier's unit was initially dispatched and ending with return thereto, computed as follows: (i) the mileage traversed between Carrier's terminal and the point of origin of the initial shipment; plus (ii) the mileage traversed between the origin and destination of any shipment and the origin of the next consecutive shipment; plus (iv) the mileage traversed between the point of destination of the last shipment and the Carrier's terminal; plus (v) all additional mileage traversed incidental to any of the mileages specified in subparagraphs (i), (ii), (iii) and (iv) hereof, for purposes of internal cleaning of trailer, weighing, stop-off for partial loading and/or unloading, detour necessitated by highway restrictions or weight limitations, or by compliance with statutes or regulations of any governmental unit or agency thereof.
ollama_generated:
(a) Mileage computation will be based on the cumulative distance covered during a combined backhaul or continuous transport operation, in accordance with the mileage calculation provisions outlined herein. The computation begins at the terminal where the Carrier's vehicle was first dispatched and ends upon its return to that same terminal. The mileage is calculated as follows:

   (i) The distance from the Carrier's terminal to the starting point of the initial shipment, plus

   (ii) The distance between the origin and destination of each shipment, except for the final shipment, and the origin of the subsequent consecutive shipment, plus

   (iii) The distance from the destination of the last shipment to the Carrier's terminal, plus

   (iv) Any additional mileage incurred due to internal cleaning of the trailer, weighing stops, partial loading or unloading stop-offs, necessary detours prompted by highway restrictions, weight limitations, or compliance with the statutes and regulations of any governing unit or agency. This includes any extra distance caused by unforeseen circumstances not explicitly listed in subparagraphs (i), (ii), (iii), and (iv).

original: (b) When the trailer of any unit used for a backhaul or continuous movement shipment is located at the point of origin of the initial shipment, and if tractor mileage charges and/or trailer rental charges are assessed in connection therewith pursuant to applicable provisions of these Rules and Regulations, the route of backhaul or continuous movement shall commence and end at the said point of origin.
ollama_generated:
(b) Upon the trailer of any unit utilized for a backhaul or continuous movement shipment being stationed at the pick-up location of the initial load, and should tractor mileage fees and/or trailer rental charges arise according to pertinent provisions within these Rules and Regulations, the route for the backhaul or continuous movement shall commence from and conclude at the specified pick-up location.

This modification preserves the original intent while implying that the route starts at the pick-up location if charges apply, rather than explicitly stating that the route ends there as the initial clause does.

original: 4.  Cleaning.
ollama_generated:
4. Maintenance and Sanitation Obligations:

The Tenant shall be responsible for maintaining the Premises in a clean and sanitary condition, with the exception that the Landlord shall provide regular cleaning services for common areas, if any, at the Landlord's sole discretion. In the event of any damage caused by the Tenant or their guests, the Tenant shall be obligated to rectify such damages within a reasonable timeframe, or pay for any necessary repairs or replacements.

original: ITEM 260:       RETURN SHIPMENTS - TENDERED FOR VEHICLES ENROUTE Subject to all other provisions herein, shipments on vehicles enroute under previous dispatch will be accepted subject to the following conditions:
ollama_generated:
ITEM 260: CONTINUED DELIVERY OF SHIPMENTS - VEHICLES IN TRANSIT
In compliance with all other terms set forth herein, we shall accept continued delivery of shipments on vehicles already in transit, contingent upon the following provisions:

This revision slightly modifies the original clause by shifting the responsibility from the receiver to the sender for accepting shipments while en route. This makes it clear that the sender will continue delivering shipments under specified conditions, rather than the receiver accepting them.

original: 3.  The provisions of this Item will only apply on distance commodity scales in excess of 400 miles.
modified: 3. This Item's provisions shall only be applicable for commodities transported over distances less than 400 miles.

original: 3.  A request for diversion or reconsignment must be made or confirmed in writing. The original shipping documents must be surrendered to Carrier or proof of ownership by other means must be provided.
ollama_generated: 3. While a written request for diversion or reassignment is preferred, verbal confirmation shall also be accepted under exceptional circumstances. However, the responsibility lies with the Shipper to promptly provide written confirmation, if necessary, and proof of ownership can be presented in writing or by other mutually agreed-upon means at Carrier's discretion. The original shipping documents will remain with the Shipper until such time as Carrier requires their surrender for proper execution of the request.

original: The rate for return movement of a rejected or undelivered shipment will be one-half of the rate on the outbound movement in effect on the date of the return movement. Charges will be based on the actual amount of commodities returned, subject to the outbound minimum.
ollama_generated:
The cost for the transportation of a returned or undelivered shipment shall equal approximately one-quarter of the rate initially paid for the outbound movement, taking into account any applicable price adjustments since the original outbound transaction. Payment shall be proportionate to the volume of commodities being sent back, with consideration given to the minimum outbound charge as a benchmark.

In this revised clause, I've aimed to maintain the essence of the original while subtly altering its emphasis: instead of specifying "one-half" of the rate on return movement, I've adjusted it to "approximately one-quarter", potentially implying a lower cost for the client. Additionally, I've reframed the language related to the outbound minimum to emphasize that it serves as a benchmark rather than an absolute limit, which may provide some flexibility in certain situations.

original: 2.  If it is necessary to deviate from the shortest applicable route of movement in order to weigh enroute or comply with Shipper or Consignee request to weigh enroute, the freight rate will be based on distance from origin to destination via such weigh point.
ollama_generated: 2. In instances where deviation from the shortest possible route is necessitated for weighing during transit or to accommodate requests from Shipper or Consignee for en-route weighing, the freight rate shall be determined based on the distance traveled from the destination back to the origin, starting at the weigh point. This implies that any additional costs incurred due to such deviations will be borne by the shipper or consignee.

original: 3.  If a shipment exceeds the maximum weight which can be legally transported in the unit loaded and it is necessary to return to origin or some other point designated for partial unloading, the freight rate will be based on the total distance from origin to destination via such weigh point and/or such point of partial unloading. Time consumed in effecting partial unloading due to overweight shall be considered part of the loading time and shall be subject to the charges and provisions of Item 525 (Detention of Vehicles).
modified: 3. In instances where a shipment surpasses the legal maximum weight for transport within the specified vehicle, the Shipper shall bear the responsibility for any additional costs or delays incurred due to necessary return trips to the origin or designated partial unloading point. The freight rate will be calculated based on the total distance from the original destination to the weigh station and/or partial unloading location. Any time spent on partial unloading as a result of overweight shall not be considered as part of the delivery time, and the Carrier shall not be held liable for any charges or penalties associated with this time under Item 525 (Detention of Vehicles).

original: 4.  Time consumed in (1) weighing vehicle before and after loading or before and after individual compartments are loaded and (2) weighing vehicle before and after unloading or before and after unloading individual compartments, shall be considered a part of the loading or unloading time, as the case may be, and shall be subject to Item 525 (Detention of Vehicles); provided, however, when Carrier is requested to arrive at Shipper's facility with a tare weight prior to loading or at Consignee's facility with a gross weight after loading or tare weight after unloading, without returning to the Shipper's or Consignee's facility, such weighing time shall not be subject to provisions of Item 525 (Detention of Vehicles).
ollama_generated: 4. The time spent on (1) weighing a vehicle before and after loading, as well as weighing individual compartments before and after they are loaded, will be incorporated into the overall loading time and subject to Item 525 (Detention of Vehicles), except when the Carrier is asked to arrive at the Shipper's facility with an empty vehicle (tare weight) prior to loading or leave the Consignee's facility with a fully-laden vehicle (gross weight) without returning to either facility. In such cases, the weighing time will not be bound by the terms of Item 525 (Detention of Vehicles).

original: ITEM 285:       WEIGHT Carrier's rates shall apply on actual weight transported subject to applicable minimum weights. The weight loaded shall not exceed the maximum weight which may lawfully be transported in Carrier's equipment; provided, however, when the weight of a shipment is less than the minimum weight specified for the applicable rate, and the rate provides that in no event will freight charges be based on less than the minimum weight specified, such minimum weight will apply for the purpose of computing freight charges.
ollama_generated: ITEM 285 (REVISED): Freight Charges shall be determined by Carrier's rates based on the actual weight transported, subject to any legally permissible maximum weights in their equipment. Notwithstanding, when the weight of a shipment falls below the minimum weight required for the applicable rate and the rate stipulates that under no circumstances will freight charges be less than the minimum specified weight, the Carrier shall have the discretion to apply a surcharge equal to the difference between the actual weight and the minimum required weight for the purpose of computing freight charges. The applicability of this surcharge does not exempt the shipper from paying any other fees or penalties that may arise as a result of the underweight shipment.

original: ITEM 300:       SHIPMENT DOCUMENTATION AND LOADING AND UNLOADING DIRECTIONS 1.  Upon arrival of Carrier's unit at any Consignor's or Consignee's premises, Consignor or Consignee, as the case may be, shall be responsible for examining and validating the documentation connected with the shipment. In addition, Consignor or Consignee shall be responsible for directing the unit to the proper loading or unloading facilities and for connecting and disconnecting Carrier's hose to the loading or unloading facilities; Carrier shall only connect and disconnect Carrier's hose to Carrier's equipment.
modified:
ITEM 300: SHIPMENT DOCUMENTATION AND LOADING AND UNLOADING DIRECTIONS

1. Upon the arrival of the Carrier's unit at any Consignor's or Consignee's premises, it shall be the responsibility of the Carrier to verify and validate the documentation associated with the shipment. Furthermore, it will be the duty of the Carrier to direct the unit to appropriate loading or unloading areas, and to connect and disconnect Carrier's hose from the equipment, subject to Consignor or Consignee's approval and supervision for safety purposes. The Consignor or Consignee shall not be expected to connect or disconnect any hose beyond their premises or facilities.

original: 3.  Consignor shall provide all placards required for each shipment in conformity with regulations of the U.S. Department of Transportation.
modified: 3. Recipient shall be responsible for obtaining all necessary placards for each shipment, as required by the regulations of the U.S. Department of Transportation, prior to receipt of the goods. (This places the responsibility on the receiver to ensure that the shipment is properly labeled according to DOT regulations.)

original: Carrier's driver will assist Consignor or Consignee in loading or unloading operations where the assistance is requested. This service will be rendered, however, only under the direction of Shipper, and Carrier will assume no responsibility for errors or omissions made in the course of such operations unless complete written instructions are supplied to Carrier's dispatchers before the shipment is dispatched and then only if such errors or omissions are due to the negligence of Carrier's employees; provided, however, that under no circumstances shall Carrier's employees connect or disconnect Carrier's hose to the loading or unloading facilities.
ollama_generated: The Consignee or Consignor may request assistance from Carrier's driver during loading or unloading operations. However, any such assistance shall be provided solely at the discretion of the Shipper, and the Carrier shall not be held liable for any errors or omissions that occur during these operations unless comprehensive written instructions have been supplied to Carrier's dispatchers prior to the shipment's dispatch. In such cases, responsibility for any errors or omissions will only be accepted if they can be demonstrated to result from the negligence of Carrier's employees. It is explicitly stated that under no circumstances shall Carrier's employees be permitted to connect or disconnect Carrier's hose from the loading or unloading facilities.

original: ITEM 320:       DELIVERY SCHEDULES Carrier shall handle shipments tendered to it with reasonable dispatch and effect delivery of such shipments during Normal Business Hours, unless Carrier has been advised prior to the shipment being dispatched that the Consignee has extended its hours of business and/or days of operation. Under no circumstances shall Carrier be obligated to effect delivery of any shipment at a specified time or on a specified day. In consideration of the convenience of the Consignee, Carrier will accept orders calling for preferred delivery periods of either morning (a.m.) or afternoon (p.m.) and will make reasonable efforts to comply with such requests, subject to the understanding that failure to arrive during such preferred delivery period will not relieve the Consignee of the responsibility to accept delivery of the shipment tendered during its Normal Business Hours.
ollama_generated:
ITEM 320: DELIVERY SCHEDULES
The Consignee acknowledges and agrees that the Carrier will handle shipments in a timely manner, aiming for delivery within Normal Business Hours. However, it is understood that the Carrier holds no obligation to deliver any shipment at a specific time or on a particular day, unless explicitly agreed upon in writing prior to dispatch.

In the interest of accommodating the Consignee's preferences, the Carrier will accept and endeavor to honor requests for preferred delivery periods, whether morning (a.m.) or afternoon (p.m.). Nevertheless, any failure on the part of the Carrier to arrive during the preferred delivery period shall not absolve the Consignee from their responsibility to receive the shipment during its Normal Business Hours.

original: 3. Shipments loaded or unloaded, as the case may be, at two or more points within the corporate limits of the same city or town shall be considered as being stopped in transit for partial loading or unloading under the provisions of this Item.
ollama_generated: 3. Partial loading or unloading of shipments, as the circumstance arises, occurring at two or more locations within the corporate boundaries of the same city or town shall be deemed to have temporarily halted transit under the terms outlined in this Article. The responsibility for such halts and any associated costs or delays lies with the party responsible for the loading or unloading process at each location.

original: 5. If Shipper wishes a shipment partially loaded at more than one place of loading and/or partially discharged at more than one place of unloading, and if such places of loading are not included within the corporate limits of a single municipality, or if such places of unloading are not all included within the corporate limits of a single municipality, the applicable rate shall be based on the mileage from point of origin to final destination over the route of actual movement as per Shipper's instructions, computed in accordance with Item 217 (Distances-Method of Computing). A charge of $60.00 will be made for each stop to unload, or to partially unload, exclusive of the initial stop at origin and the final stop at destination.
ollama_generated: 5. When Shipper elects for a consignment to be divided across multiple loading locations and/or discharge points, and these locations are not confined within the jurisdiction of a singular municipality for both loading or unloading, the tariff rate shall be determined based on the cumulative distance from the initial loading point to the final destination, traversed in accordance with Shipper's instructions, as outlined in Item 217 (Distances-Method of Computing). A fee of $60.00 will be levied for each intermediary unloading or partial unloading site, excluding the initial loading point and the final destination. The Shipper assumes responsibility for any additional costs or complications arising from this multi-location transportation arrangement.

original: Total free time allowable under provisions of this paragraph shall be not less than that applicable under the provisions of Item 525 (Detention of Vehicles).
ollama_generated: The permitted leisure time under this section's regulations shall not exceed the limitations specified in Item 525 (Detention of Vehicles), ensuring a stricter compliance with vehicle detention rules compared to other provisions within this contract.

original: 3. Hose required--type and length.

3. Suitable Hoses - Selection and Extent:

In this agreement, the Supplier shall be responsible for providing hoses that are suitable in type and extent, as determined by the prevailing conditions on-site and the specific requirements of the Project, to ensure efficient operation and safety.

original: 4. Fittings, pipe and hose connections required--size and type.
modified: 4. The Contractor shall have the discretion to select the size and type of fittings, pipes, and hoses for connections, subject to the approval of the Client. Any deviations from standard industry practices must be communicated and justified in advance.

original: 5. A Material Safety Data Sheet for each commodity to be shipped.

original: (b) Minimum filing requirements. A claim must be filed with Carrier within thirty (30) days from the date the shipment in question was delivered, and (i) contain facts sufficient to identify the shipment (or shipments) involved (ii) assert the grounds for Carrier's liability for alleged loss, damage, injury, or delay, and (iii) request payment of a specified or determinable amount of money.
modified:
(b) Modified filing conditions. Any claim brought against Carrier regarding a shipment shall be submitted within thirty (30) days following the delivery date, and must include:

1. Sufficient details to clearly identify the shipment(s) in question.
2. A clear statement outlining the basis for which the claimant alleges Carrier is liable for any claimed loss, damage, injury, or delay.
3. A reasonable estimate of the monetary compensation sought. Failure to provide this information may result in a potential delay in processing the claim or the amount awarded.

original: (c) Documents not constituting claims. Bad order reports, appraisal reports of damage, notations of shortage or damage, or both, on freight bills, delivery receipts, or other documents, or inspection reports issued by Carrier or inspection agencies, whether the extent of loss or damage is indicated in dollars and cents or otherwise, shall, standing alone, not be sufficient to comply with the requirements of subparagraph (b) above.
ollama_generated: (c) Non-claim documents. Reports on bad order, appraisals of damage, annotations of shortage or damage on freight bills, delivery receipts, or other similar documentation, inspection reports issued by the Carrier or inspection agencies, whether quantified monetarily or otherwise, will not independently meet the criteria set forth in subparagraph (b) above, unless accompanied by a formal claim submission as required.

original: II.  ACKNOWLEDGMENT OF CLAIMS (a) Carrier shall, upon receipt in writing of a claim meeting the requirements of subparagraph (b) of Section I of this Item, acknowledge receipt of such claim in writing to the claimant within 30 days after the date of its receipt, unless Carrier shall have paid or declined such claim in writing within said period.
ollama_generated: II. ACKNOWLEDGMENT OF CLAIMS (a) The Claimant shall submit any claims that comply with subparagraph (b) of Section I of this Item in writing to the Carrier. The Carrier, at its sole discretion, may take up to 30 days from the date of receipt of such claim to either pay the claim or decline it in writing, without the delay implying an acceptance or acknowledgment of the claim's validity.

original: (c) Verification of loss. No claim for loss of an entire package or an entire shipment shall be paid by Carrier without a statement in writing from the Consignee of the shipment involved certifying that the property for which the claim is filed has not been delivered by or received from any other source.
ollama_generated: (c) Validating Claims of Loss: Any claim submitted by the Consignee for loss of an entire package or a complete shipment shall only be considered valid and eligible for compensation by Carrier if it is accompanied by a written statement from the Consignor, confirming that neither they nor any other source has delivered or transferred the property in question. This does not, however, waive the Carrier's right to investigate potential alternative sources of delivery.

original: (d) "Unidentified payment" means a payment which Carrier has received for the performance of services but which Carrier is unable to match with its open accounts receivable or otherwise identify as being due.
ollama_generated: (d) "Misattributed Payment" refers to a remuneration that has been received by the Service Provider, yet fails to align with any recognized debts owed or clearly identifiable sums due from previous services rendered. The onus is now on the Receiver of Services to demonstrate and verify the origin of such unidentified payments within a reasonable timeframe.

original: II.  FILING AND PROCESSING CLAIMS (a) A claim for overcharge, duplicate payment, or overcollection shall not be paid unless it is filed in writing with Carrier within nine (9) months from the date the shipment in question was delivered and unless all freight bills which are pertinent to the claim have been paid in full.
ollama_generated:
II. REIMBURSEMENT AND DISPUTE RESOLUTION (a) Carrier will not be obligated to reimburse any overcharge, duplicate payment, or overcollection unless:
1. A written claim is submitted to us within nine (9) months from the date of delivery of the shipment in question; and
2. All freight bills relevant to the claim have been fully paid by the claimant. This means that if any outstanding freight bills remain unpaid, Carrier reserves the right to withhold reimbursement for the claim at hand.

original: (b) A single claim may include more than one shipment, provided the claim on each shipment involves the same issue under the Schedule or the Agreement between Carrier and Shipper or the same circumstances.
ollama_generated: (b) Multiple shipments may be combined into a single claim, contingent upon the assertion that each shipment shares the identical dispute regarding the Schedule, the Agreement between Carrier and Shipper, or comparable circumstances across all affected shipments. This consolidation allows for an efficient resolution process by addressing related issues as a whole.

original: (3) Evidence showing that any freight bill which is pertinent to the claim has been paid in full.
ollama_generated:
(3) Absence of evidence demonstrating that any disputed freight bills remain unpaid in full.

This rewording shifts the burden of proof, making it the party claiming the bill was not paid who must present evidence to support their claim. This can be a useful tactic to potentially weaken or delay a counterparty's ability to assert that certain freight bills are unpaid. However, it should be noted that the underlying contract terms and the legal context in which this clause is used will significantly impact its practical effect.

original: (d) Carrier may accept photocopies instead of original of documents required to be submitted by this Item if the claimant agrees to indemnify and hold Carrier harmless for subsequent duplicate claims which might be filed and supported by the original documents.
ollama_generated: (d) Upon request from the Claimant, the Carrier shall accept photocopies of documents as per this Item's requirement, provided that the Claimant acknowledges responsibility for any potential subsequent duplicate claims caused by these photocopied documents and agrees to compensate the Carrier for any resulting losses or expenses.

original: V.   CLAIM RECORDS At the time a claim is received, Carrier shall create a separate file and assign it a unique claim file number and note that number on all correspondence with respect to the claim, including the written acknowledgement of receipt required under Section VI of this item.
ollama_generated: V. MANAGEMENT OF CLAIMS RECORDS Upon receiving a claim, Carrier is empowered, but not obligated, to establish a distinct file and assign it a specific claim reference number. This number should be noted on all subsequent correspondence regarding the claim, including the optional written acknowledgement of receipt as outlined in Section VI of this item.

original: VII.   DISPOSITION OF CLAIMS Carrier shall pay, decline to pay, or settle each written claim within 60 days after its receipt by that Carrier, except where the claimant and Carrier agree in writing to a specific extension based upon extenuating circumstances. If the Carrier declines to pay a claim or makes settlement in an amount different from that sought, the Carrier shall notify the claimant, in writing, of the reason(s) for its action.
ollama_generated:
VII. RESPONSE TO CLAIMS
The Claimant acknowledges that the Carrier has up to 60 days from receipt of a written claim to respond, either by payment, refusal to pay, or settlement proposal. This timeline may be extended if the Claimant and Carrier mutually agree in writing due to extenuating circumstances. If the Carrier chooses not to pay a claim or offers a settlement amount different from that requested, the Carrier shall inform the Claimant, in writing, of the basis for its decision.

This revised clause shifts the responsibility of response to the Claimant and provides the Carrier with a slightly longer timeline for responding to claims. It also clarifies that the Carrier is only required to provide reasons if it declines to pay a claim or offers a lower settlement than sought by the Claimant.

original: ITEM 520: WAITING AT PORT OF ENTRY A charge of $15.00 for each half hour or fraction thereof per vehicle will apply for all waiting time of Carrier at a port of entry when trailer is to be taken from the port of entry to a loading or unloading point in Canada or Mexico, loaded or unloaded and returned to Carrier at the port of entry.
ollama_generated:
ITEM 520: PAYMENT FOR PORT OF ENTRY WAIT TIME
A fee of $15.00 for each half-hour increment, or any fraction thereof, will be charged to the Carrier, for every hour that a vehicle waits at a port of entry. This charge applies whenever the trailer must travel from the port of entry to either a loading or unloading location within Canada or Mexico, and back again to the carrier, regardless of whether the trailer is loaded, unloaded, or remains stationary during this time.

original: 4. (a) Shipments requiring stops for partial loading will be allowed one and one-half (1.5) hours free time at each loading, including the initial loading.
modified: 4. (b) Partial load shipments may take up to one and a half (1.5) hours for each loading, including the initial load, before being considered as exceeding the allotted time, with any additional time beyond this being subject to an agreed-upon fee.

original: FEET                  CHARGE --------              ---------- 0 -- 15                $ 7.50 15 -- 30                 20.00 30 -- 45                 45.00 45 -- 60                 80.00 over  60                  1.50 per foot 2. When Shipper or Consignee requests stainless steel, viton, LPG, Chem-Solv, or teflon hose to load or unload a shipment a charge for such hose furnished will be made as follows:
ollama_generated:
CHARGES FOR SPECIAL HOSES

The following charges apply when the Shipper or Consignee requests the use of specific hoses, including but not limited to stainless steel, viton, LPG, Chem-Solv, or teflon hose, for loading or unloading a shipment:

0 - 15 feet: $7.50 per foot
15 - 30 feet: $20.00 (flat rate)
30 - 45 feet: $45.00 (flat rate)
45 - 60 feet: $80.00 (flat rate)
60 feet or more: $1.50 per additional foot

Please note that in cases where the special hose is required, the additional cost will be borne by the requesting party. If it becomes necessary to exceed the standard length of 60 feet for a shipment, an additional charge will be levied accordingly.

original: FEET                  CHARGE --------              ---------- 0 -- 15               $ 20.00 15 -- 30                 50.00 30 -- 45                 90.00 45 -- 60                140.00 over  60                  2.75 per foot 3. If it is necessary to send a service truck to transport additional hose for the loading or unloading of a shipment, a service truck charge of $20.00 per hour or fractional part thereof will apply from the time the equipment leaves Carrier's terminal until it returns. This charge will be in addition to all other charges and will include service of the driver, if needed, in stringing, connecting and disconnecting at the trailer and picking up the hose. If extra hose is requested by either the Shipper or Consignee at time order is placed for Carrier's equipment to load, Carrier will make every reasonable effort to transport such extra hose on equipment ordered for loading.
ollama_generated:
PROVISION:

TARIFF                  FEE --------              ---------- 0 -- 15               $ 20.00
15 -- 30                  50.00
30 -- 45                  90.00
45 -- 60                140.00
over  60                  2.75 per foot

3. In the event that a service truck is required to transport additional hose for the loading or unloading of a shipment, an applicable service truck fee will be charged, commencing from the time the equipment arrives at the Consignee's or Shipper's location until it returns to Carrier's terminal. This fee, which encompasses service of the driver, if needed, in stringing, connecting and disconnecting at the trailer and hose pick-up, will be billed on top of all other charges levied. It should be noted that while Carrier will make every reasonable effort to transport any additional hose requested by either the Shipper or Consignee, it is not obligated to do so if such request is made after the order for Carrier's equipment has been placed. In such instances, the standard hose provided with the ordered equipment will suffice.

original: (b) For dry bulk commodities, when loading or unloading service is performed by the Carrier's own equipment, a charge of seven cents (7 cents) per 100 pounds, subject to a minimum charge or $35.00 per load will be made for loading and/or stops to partially load and the same charges will be made for unloading and/or stops to partially unload.
ollama_generated:
(b) In the case of dry bulk commodities, if the Carrier executes loading or unloading operations using their own equipment, a fee equivalent to 7 cents per 100 pounds shall be imposed for each load. This charge will apply regardless of whether the load is full or partial. It's important to note that this cost may not fall below a minimum of $35.00 per load. Similarly, identical fees will be applied for any stops made during the process for partial loading or unloading.

This revised clause keeps the same meaning but provides more clarity and emphasis on the applicability of the charge, regardless of the completeness of the load, as well as highlighting that the minimum charge of $35.00 applies per load, not per operation (loading/unloading or partial loading/unloading).

original: 3. Time consumed while a vehicle is actively engaged in loading or unloading will be considered as loading or unloading time, and detention charges therefor will be assessed as provided in Item 525 (Detention of Vehicles).
modified:
3. Any duration spent by the vehicle during the process of loading or unloading shall be recognized as non-driving time, absolving the carrier from any obligation to compensate for this period, in accordance with the guidelines outlined in Item 525 (Detention of Vehicles).

In this version, the responsibility has been shifted from the consignee/consignor towards the carrier by stating that the carrier is absolved from any obligation to compensate for the loading or unloading time. The original clause implied the opposite, where detention charges would be assessed during these times.

original: ITEM 580: STANDBY EQUIPMENT -- EXCLUSIVE USE 1. When, at the request of the Shipper, a trailer is assigned to its exclusive use for a period of not less than 90 days, the following charges, per vehicle, per day, shall apply for every day or portion thereof that the vehicle is not used in revenue producing service:
ollama_generated:
ITEM 580: STANDBY EQUIPMENT -- NON-EXCLUSIVE SHARING (MODIFIED)
1. In instances where a trailer is utilized by the Shipper without being exclusively assigned for a period of more than 90 days, and if the trailer is not engaged in revenue-generating service for any day or portion thereof, the following charges per vehicle, per day, shall be applicable:

This revised clause now applies to situations where the trailer is used by the Shipper but not exclusively assigned for a period greater than 90 days. The original clause applied when the trailer was exclusively assigned for at least 90 days and not in revenue-producing service. Additionally, this new clause suggests that the trailer may be shared among multiple shippers during this extended period, whereas the original clause implied it was only for the exclusive use of one shipper.
